question: In the previous chapter, we looked at the broad classification of living organisms under the system proposed by ______ (1969).
Whittaker suggested the Five Kingdom classification viz. Monera, Protista, ______, Animalia and Plantae.
Whittaker suggested the Five Kingdom classification viz. Monera, ______, Fungi, Animalia and Plantae.
Whittaker suggested the Five Kingdom classification viz. Monera, Protista, Fungi, Animalia and ______.
In this chapter, we will deal in detail with further classification within Kingdom ______.
Kingdom Plantae is popularly known as the ‘______ kingdom’.
Our understanding of the plant kingdom has ______ over time.
Fungi, and members of the Monera and Protista having ______ ______ have now been excluded from Plantae.
Earlier classifications placed Monera, Protista, and Fungi in the same ______.
Cyanobacteria are also referred to as ______ ______ algae.
Cyanobacteria are not considered ‘______’ any more.
In this chapter, we will describe Algae, Bryophytes, ______, Gymnosperms and Angiosperms under Plantae.
We will describe Algae, Bryophytes, Pteridophytes, Gymnosperms and ______ under Plantae.
Let us also look at classification within ______ to understand some of the concerns that influenced classification systems.
The earliest systems of classification used only gross superficial ______ characters.
The earliest classification systems considered habit, colour, number and shape of ______.
The earliest classification systems were based mainly on ______ characters.
Some classification systems were based on the ______ structure.
The system based on androecium structure was given by ______.
The earliest classification systems were ______ as they separated closely related species.
Artificial systems gave equal weightage to vegetative and ______ characteristics.
Vegetative characters are more easily affected by the ______.
Natural classification systems were based on natural ______ among organisms.
Natural classification systems consider not only external but also ______ features.
Natural classification systems consider ultra-structure, anatomy, embryology and ______.
A natural classification for flowering plants was given by George ______ and Joseph Dalton Hooker.
A natural classification for flowering plants was given by George Bentham and ______ ______ Hooker.
Fungi, and members of Monera and Protista having cell walls have now been ______ from Plantae.
Earlier classifications placed Fungi in the same kingdom as ______.
Classification systems based only on a few characteristics are known as ______ systems.
Artificial classification systems separated closely ______ species.
Natural classification systems developed as an alternative to ______ classification systems.
Natural classification systems consider internal features like anatomy and ______.
Vegetative characters are not reliable because they are more easily affected by ______.
The classification system given by Linnaeus is based on the structure of ______.
Systems that gave equal weight to vegetative and sexual characters are considered ______.
George Bentham and Joseph Dalton Hooker gave a classification for ______ plants.
Natural systems consider both external and ______ features of plants.
The term 'plant kingdom' is popularly used for Kingdom ______.
We will describe ______, Bryophytes, Pteridophytes, Gymnosperms and Angiosperms under Plantae.
Members of Monera and Protista with cell walls were earlier placed in the same ______ as plants.
Such systems that use superficial morphological characters are called ______ systems.
Systems that rely on habit, colour and shape of leaves are considered ______.
Systems using natural affinities among organisms are known as ______ classification systems.
The natural classification system takes into account phytochemistry and ______ structure.
Artificial systems separated species that were actually ______ related.
The androecium is a part of the ______ reproductive system.
Systems based only on androecium structure ignore many other ______ features.
Phytochemistry refers to the study of ______ compounds in plants.
Joseph Dalton Hooker was one of the scientists who proposed a ______ classification system.
